awd_titl_txt: CRI: II-New: A Software Defined Infrastructure for Cross-Layer Research on Reconfigurable Architecture and Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Rapid advances in computer technologies bring many disruptive changes to conventional wisdoms of software and hardware systems. Such disruption requires the increasing attention and efforts from computing researchers to develop commensurate software and hardware tools that can facilitate the service of computer technologies to the applications and end users. Significant research on computer architecture, network, and storage systems is needed to meet these requirements. The Department of Computer Science at Florida State University has been carrying out many systems research projects that could make use of cutting-edge equipment on software defined networking, processor and memory architectures, high-bandwidth storage devices, and reconfigurable computer systems. 

To meet the need, this project develops a software-defined, reconfigurable infrastructure called NoleLand. It features advanced manycore processors, software-defined networking, and 3D Xpoint High Bandwidth Memory devices for computer systems research. These capabilities enable cross-layer research projects on performance, scalability, and resilience of large-scale systems, as well as the development of software-defined file and storage systems for data-intensive applications. In addition, NoleLand provides an incubator for more collaborative opportunities and multidisciplinary research projects. Furthermore, NoleLand helps recruit more under-represented Hispanic and African-American students and prepares them for professional careers. It delivers a state-of-the-art infrastructure that significantly strengthens computing research and education activities at the Florida State University and the local community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project develops a software-defined, reconfigurable infrastructure called NoleLand. It features advanced manycore processors, software-defined networking, and 3D Xpoint High Bandwidth Memory devices for computer systems research. NoleLand delivers a state-of-the-art infrastructure that significantly strengthens computing research and education activities at the Florida State University. It enables cross-layer research projects on performance, scalability, and resilience of large-scale systems, as well as the development of software-defined file and storage systems for data-intensive applications. It also has profound impact in strengthening computing curriculum and enhancing education activities for students at FSU, particularly its diverse set of under-represented Hispanic and African-American students and preparing them for professional computing careers.

 

Delivering a Cutting-Edge Software-Defined Computing Infrastructure

We have overcome a lot of administrative and logistic hurdles for the deployment of NoleLand in two phases. The first phase of the procurement has included the following components: (1) one master node with 8TB RAID-5 storage; (2) one FPGA server; (3) ten dual-socket 16-core/32- thread servers; (4) InfiniBand HDR switch and HCA adaptors; (5) one SDN-capable management switch and four SDN-capable 25-Gigabit Ethernet switches; and (6) one server rack and three PDUs. All the nodes are equipped with 240GB solid-state drivers and one 2TB hard drive for capacity storage. The NoleLand cluster is managed by the FSU research computing center and the department of computer science. The first phase of NoleLand was opened up for user services since Fall 2019.

For the second phase of the NoleLand cluster, we have categorized our requirements in two lots based on latest product offerings from various vendors on accelerators, network and storage devices. Lot 1 consists of computations servers with three different kinds of GPU accelerators (NVLink based V100, PCI-E V100 and T4 from NVIDIA) and Intel and AMD servers. Lot 2 consists of persistent NVDIMM memory modules, Intel Optane SSD devices, and an InfiniBand network. The outbreak of covid-19 pandemic delayed the procurement and deployment of the second phase until the end of 2020. The company named Atipa won the bid for the 2nd phase of NoleLand and their technicians finished an initial installation of the servers.

NoleLand has been fully operational since March 2021. The main activities since then have been on maintaining its smooth operation and supporting system reconfigurations as needed by various research projects. All users are required to acknowledge the NSF award on their publications enabled by NoleLand.

Students Training for NoleLand Administration and Operation:

Because of the pandemic, limited assistance from graduate students was obtained for the installation of the cluster. The PIs managed to work with the systems group from the Computer System department, particularly for the NoleLand second phase. In total, four graduate students (Rupak Roy, Subhadeep Bhattacharya, Fahim Chowdhury and Fazle Rahat) have directly participated in the maintenance and operational activities of NoleLand.

Thesis/Dissertation and Research Publications Enabled by NoleLand:

We have enabled many collaborative research projects on the cluster by disseminating the capabilities of NoleLand to more local and remote users and cultivating more interdisciplinary research and education activities with internal and external collaborators.

We have had more 40 active users since the operation of NoleLand. Our project has enabled more education and training opportunities for K-12, undergraduate, master and doctoral graduate students. Saul Parades, Alexander De Sabatino, Zack Lin, and Nicholas Funguy with their CS bachelor’s degrees in May 2019 and May 2020, respectively. Five master students (Harsh Kundnani, Rupak Roy, Subhadeep Bhattacharya, one Hispanic Arthur Karapateas and one female Abigail Mortensen) have graduated with their research partly enabled by the project. Seven PhD students have graduated with their research partly enabled by the Noleland cluster. Specifically, Yue Zhu, Muhib Khan, Fahim Chowdhury, Abu Naser, Michael Stokes, Mehran Sadeghi Lahijani, and Mohsen Gavahi have graduated with their PhD degrees and joined IBM, Facebook, Amazon, Intel, AMD, Oracle, Exascale Systems, respectively.

All dissertations and master theses have been published through Florida State University library. The research papers have been published in various journals and conferences. The detailed list is available in the final project.
